head.title: Pleasures of the Mind, Soul and Palate

hedline.hl1: Pleasures of the Mind, Soul and Palate

block.p: Seattle is 2,895 miles northwest of New York City. Here is a sampling of attractions, along with travel information:
Where to Stay

ALEXIS, 1007 First Avenue, (206) 624-4844. A graceful, century-old 109-room classic, this is a member of the boutique chain assembled by the California hotelier Bill Kimpton. The public spaces are filled with the work of regional artists (including several vibrant Dale Chihuly glass sculptures), and the bright bedrooms are decorated with cheerful, traditional fabrics. No view, but you waken to the sound of sea gulls and foghorns. Terrific Aveda spa. Double rooms from $230.
Seattle is 2,895 miles northwest of New York City. Here is a sampling of attractions, along with travel information:
Where to Stay

ALEXIS, 1007 First Avenue, (206) 624-4844. A graceful, century-old 109-room classic, this is a member of the boutique chain assembled by the California hotelier Bill Kimpton. The public spaces are filled with the work of regional artists (including several vibrant Dale Chihuly glass sculptures), and the bright bedrooms are decorated with cheerful, traditional fabrics. No view, but you waken to the sound of sea gulls and foghorns. Terrific Aveda spa. Double rooms from $230.

FOUR SEASONS OLYMPIC, 411 University Street, (206) 621-1700. Grand with a capital G: a lobby straight from a Renaissance palace, a blossom-filled garden court, a shopping arcade where you can buy a ball gown or an antique candelabrum, and a windowed rooftop pool. This is a dowager, built in the 1920's, but very well preserved. Even the smaller rooms have duvets and luxurious bathrooms. Do you need a notary public, a shoe shine or maybe a car wash? Just ask. Double rooms from $230.

INN AT THE MARKET, 86 Pine Street, (206) 443-3600. Lean, understated, enlivened with touches of Asia and Provence, this is a discreetly distinguished little hotel -- especially if you can snag a room like 514, a suite that looks down on the Pike Place Market and beyond to Elliott Bay and the peaks of the Olympic Peninsula. Fax machines, kitchenettes and even orchids in the bedrooms. Betsey and I wish there were one of these in every city we visit. Double rooms from $170.

W, 1112 Fourth Avenue, (206) 264-6000. Hard-edged, high-tech decor, soft-edged service from a black-clad staff -- an apt combination for Seattle. The lobby is small, crowded and noisy, but the 428 guest rooms are quiet and comfortable, with 250-count sheets and CD libraries. The restaurant, Earth & Ocean, is the latest brainstorm of the mini-mogul Drew Nieporent. But the coveted silver ''W'' yo-yo's are available only through the catalog. Double rooms from $239.
Where to Eat

CAMPAGNE, 86 Pine Street, (206) 728-2800. Peter Lewis, a model of warmth and charm, offers deeply satisfying French food, steering a course north of bistro banality and south of nouvelle nonsense. One night recently, my tart of crunchy, slightly sour chard made an ideal introduction to a dish of unctuous braised pork cheeks. Betsey's seafood boudin, though lighter, was no less tasty. The wines, mostly French, are carefully chosen and gently priced.

CANLIS, 2576 Aurora Avenue, (206) 283-3313. Fifty years old this year, a classic room in stone and redwood cantilevered over Lake Union, Canlis has been revitalized by a new chef, Greg Atkinson. He has nudged the menu toward seasonal and regional authenticity with lime-seasoned raw Alaskan scallops and Frog Hollow Farm peaches, while keeping the succulent steaks and chops that made the house's name. The service is silky, the wine list the area's best.

DAHLIA LOUNGE, 2001 Fourth Avenue, (206) 682-4142. Tom Douglas is Seattle's premier restaurateur, and this is his premier restaurant. Japanese lanterns, red walls and music from the 30's, 40's and 50's cast a casual glow over the delicious Asian-accented food. Six little fishy bites (for example, albacore with ponzu sauce) come nestled in ice; a slab of grilled Alaska king salmon rests on a chowder of tart sorrel leaves and sweet corn. Coconut cream pie with fresh coconut for dessert. No wonder they shot a scene for ''Sleepless in Seattle'' here a few years back.

HERBFARM, 195 Northeast Gilman Boulevard, Issaquah, (206) 784-2222. Dinner here is a major production -- nine courses, six wines, five hours, $150 a head. But it's worth all that, and the half-hour drive east of downtown, to experience the food of Jerry Traunfeld, a culinary wizard who flavors duck with lavender and wild blueberries, slow-roasts salmon in a giant zucchini blossom, and pairs melon soup with tarragon ice. The results are absolutely thrilling.

RAY'S BOATHOUSE, 6049 Seaview Avenue Northwest, (206) 789-3770. Ray's seafood is never less than impeccably fresh and soundly cooked, and on a fine summer's day what could be more enthralling than sitting on the deck, watching boats cross the sound, with a breeze mussing your hair? Manila clams steamed with beer, dill and butter, and sesame-crusted halibut with sticky rice make a dandy lunch, and there are 177 white wines to choose from. I counted.

SAZERAC, 1101 Fourth Avenue, (206) 624-7755. Sick of salmon? Had it with halibut? Jan Birnbaum, the Louisiana-born owner of Catahoula in the Napa Valley, has established a lively Seattle beachhead for the cooking of the Southeast (pork barbecue), Southwest (crab and rock shrimp enchiladas) and Cajun country (crawfish beignets). His chicken and andouille gumbo is dense and dark, full of okra, fire and file. Open all day, seven days a week.

SHIRO, 2401 Second Avenue, (206) 443-9844. This is the Plain Jane among Seattle's top restaurants, a starkly simple little place with plastic chairs and paper napkins. No matter; the sushi is superb. We especially liked the shiro roll, made with mackerel, shiso and ginger, and sea urchin roe (uni), so soft and creamy it barely clung to the rice. Wasabi is hand ground here.

WILD GINGER, 1401 Third Avenue, (206) 623-4450. Another of Seattle's favorites, Rick Yoder's pan-Asian brasserie moved this summer into handsome new multimillion-dollar quarters across the street from Benaroya Hall. It was jammed from the moment the doors opened. Japanese screens, origami lampshades and rattan chairs set just the right tone for a wide variety of satays, each served with a different sauce, and for authentic Thai and Malay curries. The baby boy choi is to die for.
Attractions

SPACE NEEDLE, 219 Fourth Avenue North, (206) 905-2100 or (800) 937-9582. Hours: Daily, 8 a.m. to midnight. Admission to observation deck: $11; $9, the elderly; $5, ages 5 to 12; 4 and under, free. There is also a revolving restaurant, SkyCity. Accessible by the Monorail; information: (206) 448-3481.

SEATTLE OPERA, Seattle Center Opera House, 321 Mercer Street, (206) 389-7676. Tonight at 7: Final performance of ''Das Rheingold,'' with Phillip Joll and Stephanie Blythe; tickets: $62 to $125. Tomorrow, Tuesday and Friday at 7 p.m.: ''Die Walkure,'' with Jane Eaglen: tickets: $40 to $125. Fall season begins Oct. 21 with ''Lucia di Lammermoor,'' with Harolyn Blackwell.

SEATTLE SYMPHONY, Benaroya Hall, 200 University Street, (206) 215-4747. On Sept. 6 and 7 at 7:30, Garrison Keillor performs with the symphony, conducted by Philip Brunelle. On Sept. 16 the symphony season opens with a gala and a concert conducted by Gerard Schwarz and runs through July. Tickets: $25 to $62.

SEATTLE MARINERS, Safeco Field, 1250 First Avenue South, at Atlantic Street (exit on Interstate 5), (206) 346-4000. No game this weekend. The Mariners play the Yankees on Aug. 28-30 at the stadium. Tickets: $5 to $32; (206) 622-4487

EXPERIENCE MUSIC PROJECT, at the base of the Space Neeedle, 325 Fifth Avenue North, (206) 367-5483. Hours through Labor Day: Daily, 9 a.m. to 11 p.m. Admission: $19.95; $15.95 for the elderly and students aged 13 to 17; $14.95 for children 6 and under.

SEATTLE ART MUSEUM, 100 University Street, (206) 654-3100. ''20th-Century American Art: The Ebsworth Collection,'' through Nov. 1. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5 for students and those over 62; children under 12, free.
SEATTLE ASIAN ART MUSEUM, 1400 East Prospect Street, Volunteer Park, (206) 654-3100. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, to 9 p.m. Admission: $3; children under 12, free.
PACIFIC NORTHWEST BALLET, Seattle Center Opera House, 321 Mercer Street, (206) 441-2424. The season begins with ''Coppelia,'' Sept. 28-30 and Oct. 5-8. Tickets: $15 to $110.

INTIMAN THEATER, Seattle Center, Second Avenue North and Mercer Street, (206) 269-1900. ''The Chairs,'' by Eugene Ionesco: Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7 p.m. Through Sept. 9. Tickets: $27.50 to $42. ''The Weir'' begins previews Sept. 15.

SEATTLE REPERTORY THEATER, Bagley Wright Theater and Leo K. Theater, Seattle Center, 155 Mercer Street, (206) 443-2222. The nine-play season begins Sept. 6 with ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe,'' starring Lily Tomlin, in the Wright. Tickets: $15 to $45. In the Leo K., ''Jar the Floor,'' by Cheryl West, opens Sept. 18. Tickets: $15 to $42.

ACT, Kreielsheimer Place, 700 Union Street, (206) 292-7676. In the Allen Theater, through Sunday, ''A Skull in Connemara'' by Martin McDonagh. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $27 to $42. In the Falls Theater, Aug. 26 through Oct. 1, the world premiere of ''In the Penal Colony,'' a new opera theater work by Philip Glass; libretto by Rudolph Wurlitzer, based on the story by Franz Kafka; directed by JoAnne Akalaitis and conducted by Alan Johnson. Tickets: $19 to $42. In the Bullitt Theater, through Sept. 10, ''St. Nicholas,'' by Conor McPherson. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; Sunday at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $15. In Busters, an open-ended run of ''Late Nite Catechism,'' by the Seattle Theater Project and Cloud 9 Productions. Thursdays through Saturdays at 8 p.m.; Sundays at 2 p.m. Tickets: $24.50 and $29.50.
Getting There

BY AIR: Continental, (800) 525-0280, has four daily nonstop flights from Newark Airport, starting at $533 round trip with a 21-day advance purchase and a Saturday stay-over. The 14-day advance purchase fare is $905 round trip. Last-minute flights cost up to $1,065 one way. American, (800) 433-7300, has one daily nonstop flight from Kennedy Airport, starting at $528 round trip with a 21-day advance purchase and a Saturday stay-over. The 14-day advance purchase fare ranges from $900 to $962. The last-minute fare costs up to $2,326, round trip. Delta, (800) 221-1212, also has one daily nonstop flight from Kennedy, with comparable fares; as does United, (800) 241-6522, with round-trip fares beginning at $780 with a 21-day advance purchase and a Saturday stay-over.
R. W. APPLE Jr.
